To be taken serious, or not?Make it Indie has received a LOT of negative comment since its release on April 1st (ahum) of this year. The description on the Steam Store page explicitly asks not to take it too seriously, and so people have mostly jumped in expecting some fun and entertainment. Which the game ... does not provide.At its core, this is a (slightly) interactive story, which "teaches" the player how to succeed or - more likely - fail at becoming a developer of Indie games. During one week you're every morning presented with a choice: to work on your game, or rather do something else. If you work on the game enough, and you succeed at the fairly stupid but not that easy clicker-mini-game, then you finish a game and it may be published. Goal accomplished.If you choose to other things, you're presented with one out of eight different full-motion video's, which feel like being directed by a decent amateur cinematograph (or first-year student) and are shot in Russia. They contain some nice images, but are mostly unsettling in their vagueness. There's no interaction at all in this part of the game: you just watch and wait (or skip and proceed to the next day, quickly getting all the achievements, but that would completely beside the point).Now, based on these all-too-meagre contents, it could be a straightforward affair, and I could dismiss this little "game" as  an utter failure. But the game has stirred something inside me while playing, something I've been thinking about. Maybe there is a "deeper" meaning to it, such as: if you do what you're expected to do (working every day on your project, in order to succeed), life is boring as hell. Which, to me, makes sense, and not at the same time. It all depends if you can put something of yourself, of your dreams maybe, into your work. But if you choose not to focus, and to do whatever you feel like doing on a given day, life becomes unsettled, even upsetting. That's where the nightmares come in: every night, there's a short but disturbing dream. Nothing spooky or horror-like, no, just unsettling. It's difficult to describe it so I suggest you just pay the dollar or euro, and go and watch (play) this.Try to do it with an open mind, not expecting some quick fun, and maybe you'll get the same feeling as I had: that this game wants to tell us something, about life, about dreams; surely in a clumsy and unpolished way, but stll: I feel there is more to it than just "a game not to be taken seriously".Recommended for the really curious, but definitely to be avoided if looking for some easy fun.

												There isn’t much of a game here.  You watch videos based on your selection and the only interactive parts are choosing what to do and the simplistic game (click on the quadrant of a circle that is in every shape) that you play in order to ‘develop’ your indie game.You can choose to develop your game or other activities like listening to music, play with your cat or go for a walk. The music consists of many Russian bands/acts that you wouldn’t have heard of unless you are a native.  The game has a quirky sense of humour which tends to fall flat.  Fortunately, all the videos can be skipped, which is a good metaphor for the game. You will unlock almost all of the achievements on your first time playing - all of them if you get the good ending.  Within half-an-hour you will have seen everything the game has to offer, and there is really no point in playing it again, unless you want the trading cards.  In the information about the game in the Steam store, the developer/publisher asks you to “Don't take this game too seriously!”  I was sent a key for the game; if you want to pay for it, bear in mind that there is not much game here, seriously.Review copy provided by Sometimes You.

There were a few movies or text between movies that actually made me laugh, as the game even pokes fun at itself. Some of the movies in the beginning seem to try to stress the feelings you might have being an indie developer, but toward the end they just get very abstract and I think the dev on this game, just went for random strange stuff that people would interpret in strange ways. Music probably could have been more interesting, but most of it was in Russian(?), and so I couldn't really understand it. Controls only exist really in the mini-game which consists of you spam clicking.... Really kinda boring and one dimensional. Visuals - I would have to say interesting, though when you're wondering if something you've seen is the same thing or if it's something different, you tend to start realizing how bored you are because you want to analyze the waking up bit. WARNING: while the game says that smoking is bad and features scenes of people smoking, what it fails to mention is that it could possibly cause someone an epileptic fit. While you have the ability to skip most movies, which would be fine if you realized in time, this particular video sequence occurs when you are supposed to be 'developing' the game (read as playing mini-game to beat the game). Was extremely short, achievements are easy to get... But still not completely what I'd call a game. Overall 4/10 - Just skip it :/

												TL;DR: A game making the point that you cannot make a game unless you devote a big chunk of your time to actually do it. There, I spoiled it for you. But then again, Make it indie! has very few actual gameplay features. It advertises that it's a game about surviving as an indie developer for a week. The problem is, it's not really a game about that. It's hardly a game at all.The concept sounds awesome. What do you have to do to make it through the week as an indie developer, to push for that deadline? Maybe you'd have to make a timetable and try to manage your time between game development, designing, art work, writing, sound design and also free time and relaxing. Require the player to put that into the right order to come up with the game. Perhaps even require keeping your hunger, exhaustion and focus at bay. Throw in a couple of events you need to take into account, like a birthday party or some special holiday. Voilà! So how's the execution of that anticipation in this game?It's poor. It's outright appalling. It's the bare bones of what I expected with fluff all over it. In the game, every day you have a choice of basically two options: either use the time for developing the game or goofing around. There are eight kinds of goofing around. Choosing any shows you a video of the developer goofing around: e.g. playing with his cat, being at a party or playing poker with his friends, with no gameplay whatsoever. Then the night comes and you get to see videos of weird dreams. They are potentially epilepsy inducing with all the flashing lights. All in all, no games were developed that day.I found these videos to be "artsy", in that bad way where you get bored and awkward and feel tempted to skip but cannot in case you miss something interesting. There's some angsty, varying music on the backgrounds of the videos. It varies from heavy metal to eerie ambience to some experimental stuff and unfortunately I liked none of it. At least every video grants you an achievement.If you instead choose to develop your game, like you probably should, you get a taunty hint of how meager your attempt is and then get to play a tedious game of "developing". It's the same game every day, just more difficult and more tedious every time because of the horrible music and varying background that camouflages the game pieces you are trying to identify. A cringing sound plays in the background making the experience agonizing (it made me take off my headphones). That seems to be the whole point too: the game developer's life is hard and boring work.I watched all the videos and played the game through to its two different endings ("bad" and "good" one) in 40 minutes and still have to idle it to get the trading cards if I care enough. It costs just 1 € so you don't lose much anything but time for it. Fortunately, its Store Page itself warns you not to take the game too seriously. My warning is this: it is not a game developing simulator. In fact, there's no game here to begin with.

   It's said, in some places around the world. That some forms of art. Like paintings, and many others. May only reach the feelings of a group of individuals, or even just one. But, since art is something that changes from person-to-person. Even  if 95% of the worlds hates it. It still can be called as Art.  This game is like non-other that you might have played in your life. In Summary i would actually say that it's an Interactive Story. With two almost certain endings:1. You create a new Minecraft. And fail with your friends, and therefore with the things that makes you a human.2. You fail with yourself. But, you will still be able to be called as a human.Now, there's another thing that this game has which any other hasn't. And maybe, not even it's developer know's that it has. And that is... This game indirectly abords the "Procratinating Act." ~~Not Wikipedia, it's basically living without producing anything, and in idle mode,~~  Now, you might be asking yourself. Especially if you already have played the game. How can this game talk about procrastinating... Well, as you start the game. You'll receive some options on what to do with your time. That's--- let's say.. some are from the "have fun type", and the other's about "wasting time./letting the time go away." And, the most important of all, work in your game. A game that have to be ready in 7 days.  Make it indie, has one of the most unique approaches to creating a game in a personal and psychological approach. Since, it talks about something i've always felt and thought about when working. And i'm sure a lot of other folks have felt it too. Which is the idea of.. Why must i do this, if i can go elsewhere and have fun?... Why must i work on this game if i can go out with my friends? Why should i dedicate my time and life into making a game, if i don't even know if people will buy it?A lot of indie developers, really go through this, since some of them have family's. family which is going to need them. along with parents who need's their support or this kind of thing... Also, you get this feeling when you are starting to work with games, and start trying to "Breach into the business".   For real, this game is unique. It has not only showed me a new vision about how i'm wasting my time/ how i should invest my time. But also made me realize that i'm not the only one with this vision about working.  The only real problem with this game is that, it's not a game at all. And, as i stated before. Some sort of intective story. At long last, If you are a developer. Or someone that likes some pretty cool russian rock. Or someone who think's that has been only procrastinating. You can buy this game. With no fear, it will be worth every coin. Besides all those negatives reviewes are it's page. ---//----Brazilian Portuguese version.---//__\\---Versão Português do Brasil.---\\----  É dito pelo mundo que formas de representação da arte, como pinturas tendem a atingir apenas um grupo de pessoas ou até mesmo uma pessoa. E pela arte ser algo subjetivo, a mesma pode ser interpretada diferentemente por cada um... Mesmo que odeiem a sua pintura, ainda será arte.  Este game não será como nenhum outro que jogou. Eu diria que é até mesmo uma historia interativa com dois finais premeditáveis.1. Você cria o próximo Minecraft. e falha com seus amigos e logo o que te faz humano.2. Você falha consigo mesmo. Mas, mantém suas amizades assim como as coisas que te fazem feliz.  Agora, o que este jogo tem que nenhum outro tem. E que talvez nem mesmo o desenvolvedor sabia que estava fazendo.. É que esse jogo aborda de leve o tema da Procrastinação. ~~Em palavras baixas, não produzir e só esperar~~  Você deve estar se perguntando como.. E se já jogou principalmente... Bem, o jogo lhe dá algumas opções para se fazer que são "do tipo diversão" ou "deixar o tempo passar." Ou, e a mais importante. Trabalhar em seu jogo. Jogo qual deve ser terminado em 7 dias. E o mais único desse jogo é que, ele aborda diretamente algo que eu sempre senti e achei muito importante e que muitas pessoas também sentem. Que é a ideia de quê~~ Para que vou fazer isso se posso ir me divertir.. Para que vou trabalhar no meu jogo se posso sair com meus amigos. Para que me dedicar nisso, se provavelmente ninguém comprará meu jogo.  Muitos desenvolvedores indie realmente passam por isso. Tanto quando você não tem muitas preocupações, como quando tem várias... Como família para cuidar, ou parentes doentes. Assim como você está começando e querendo entrar no mercado.  Este jogo é único e me mostrou que não só eu que tenho essa visão sobre desenvolver e sobre como gastar meu tempo.  O único problema deste jogo é que ele não é um jogo em si. E sim, como eu disse acima. Uma forma de história interativa.  Enfim, caso você seja um desenvolvedor ou alguém que goste de uns rocks russos bem♥♥♥♥♥♥ Pode comprar sem medo, vai valer a pena cada moeda. E caso queira confirmar o que eu disse, compre também. E tente ver o jogo com bons olhos e não com os olhos dos haters que largam análises negativas.

												This isn't a game as such, it has interactive elements but they are more of an allegory for the development process than an actual game itself.I think people are under appreciating what this actually is. It's an artistic expression representing the life a an indie developer. Working on the game option is how you come to a "good ending" but alternatively you can chose to witness 7 days of activities, normal things like watching your cat or listening to the rain. Things that might make you stop and daydream for a while. After each day however, the night ensues bringing with it the obscure fragments of discorded sounds and a malaise of out of focus images. Taking influences from every day activities is a ways of formulating ideas. Drawing from everyday life and dreams is how fantastic creations are made, be it works of art, music or games.It's an important reminder of the developers who have the skills to create but the agony of translating the realms of imagination into a format people can enjoy as a playable game.Don't be too quick to judge Make it Indie! Try to enjoy it for what it is.

												I am not as dead against this as many people are but it is not something that I can recomend to anyone. It is clearly intended as more of an interactive movie than a fully fledged game so bear that in mind if considering  a purchase. Make it Indie is a russian game designed as a jibe at the process of indie game development and can easily be seen as a take-down of the current indie game market. It contains a lot of poorly translated english but that's not surprising considering A) It's an indie game B) it's a Russian game, they were clearly not going to have enough money to get a decent translation performed. Gameplay there is very little to talk about as it consists of a manu that links to several different video clips and a singluar mini-game where you click on one of four segments of a circle. It's very basic but the 'gameplay' section is clearly intended to reflect the monotony of developing a game, this does not make it good or enjoayble however. Clearly effort has gone into this game, however it's also clear that it could have been made in a 24 hour game competition without loosing much. As for the fact is was developed using Unity Personal, so what? Unity Personal does not mean that it should not be sold. Games devloped in Unity Personal can still be sold commercially as it says in the license when you download it. CONCLUSION - 6/10Although I cannot actually recomend this game it is not at all bad for 79p (I assume prices will vary outside the UK) It is very basic but what do you expect for what it is. There is no gameplay but you might extract some pleasure through playing through it once, and if you want some quick cards/achievements then you cannot go wrong.

												I think where this developer went wrong is making people expect something that it isn't .Saying "survive the horrors" makes people think its a survival horror game- it's not.Saying "Make It Indie! is an indie game about making an indie game." makes you think you will be constructing some sort of game as part of the game. You don't. Saying "Over 30 minutes of HD videos that immerses the player" makes you think it will be artistically beautiful and atmospheric. It isn't.Saying "An intuitive gameplay experience." makes you think you're going to be introduced to some unique gameplay mechanics. It doesn't.Saying "Truly diverse music tracks." makes you think you're going to hear some engaging and immersive game music. You don't.Saying "P.S. Don't take this game too seriously!" doesn't change much.If you set your people up to think the game is something completely different than it is, you're setting yourself up for a lot of disappointed and negative reviews. The game in itself, while it is very arthouse and probably not to everyone's taste, has nothing really wrong with it. It's just that people were expecting something very different. Be more accurate in describing your next game and the people who do choose to buy your game will most likely be positive, as it will have been aimed at the right audience.

Posted: April 10, 2015
												Well, this game is a bit special. I did like it, the concept and all, but it's way too short, with very little replay values. Also, it's quite repetitive, if you actually decide to work on "your" indie game. Just like in real life. Just to say, it took me 15 minutes to get everything, and I spent the rest of the total time waiting for Steam Trading Cards.It's a really simple game. You have a week, a total of 7 actions, which consist pretty much as "Work on your indie game" or "Do not work on your indie game". Obviously, it's not /that/ obvious, but with little to no thinking, it's almost as obvious. If you decide to work, you get a little puzzle game that's quite simple at first, getting harder day after day. While, if you decide to have fun, you get treated to a short video.Basically, it's "video or logic game". You also get to see a video every night.Thought, I do have to give the game some points, since it gives a great moral lesson: "You can do everything you want, if you actually spend time towards your goals."Even if it's repetitive, boring, uninspiring, if you work toward what you want to do, if you work to do what you want, you only need to invest time in it, and eventually, you'll do it. Maybe not in a weekend.You can actually finish the game in 5 minutes, since the author thought about making a skip video button, which is sometimes a real time saver.This game is quite original, there's some place for improvements, but it gets bland and repetitive way too soon. If you're an achievement hunter or someone who wants a really cheap game on steam, this is the game for that.

												Tags : Adventure - FMV - Photo/FilmTags : Delete Local Content & Hide from LibraryTLDR : Its trashReview : Make it Indie is an interactive FMV movie with a clicker game mashed together. The whole game are 7 sections in which you can play the clicker game or watch one of the dev's amateur footage out of his russian hometown. I found the footage rather entertaining and he did put some rather neat local russian music to go along with it. The footage is meant to represent what you would do for fun activities when not actively trying to develop a game, as you are after all, an indie game dev supposed to be making a game.The first option, game development, is thus a clicker game where a circle is divided in four pie parts, you click on the pie part that all 4 pies have in common to earn a point, you must earn 77 points over the 7 maximum attempts to be ¨rewarded¨ with the ending in which you actually complete an indie game.In between each section is an abstract dream section, there are only 3 or 4 dream footages so it is very easy to see the same ones over and over again and since they are random expect to have to use that skip button.Either way in the end the game tells you that you either made a game or didnt, does not really seem to care if you did or not, and gives you the end credits. It is not all that hard to complete the game and see the totality of the content and takes about 30 to 40 minutes if you watch all the footage and replay twice I would estimateThere doesnt seem to be a very strong narrative, or message, or social commentary about game development. It is for better or for worse, exactly as I stated above, a clicker game, amateur hometown footage, and a game that tells you that what you are doing is pointlessAs an adventure game it falls flat, and provides little to no entertainment over doing nearly anything else, and it begs to question how much of the intent of this was serious and not just a cheap cash grabArtistically I will withold my commentary as I do not critique film making, but I am sure other reviewers will be helpful with that
